item.title: More Natural Deduction
item.description: A handful of students have asked for more TFL natural deduction proofs to practice. Natural deduction rules reference sheet If you want to display or print out a full list of the basic rules or derived rules for natural deduction, summarized in one place, they are listed in forall x at Appendix C 3.4 and 3.5. (In the Fall 2021 edition of the textbook, they start at page 406.) Sources for additional TFL natural deduction proofs for practicing The textbook, forall x, contains many worked examples in the middle of the chapters (especially 16 and 17) which you can try and then compare to your own answers.

item.title: Test 1
item.description: Test 1, at class time on October 18, may include the following tasks: Define “logically valid.” Answer true-false questions using the terms/concepts from the vocabulary sheet, very similar to the true-false exercises you’ve done. Look at one or more English sentences, and construct a symbolization key for the atomic TFL sentences in them—a key that is adequate to bring out their truth-functional structure. Using a given symbolization key, symbolize English sentences in TFL.

item.title: Quizzes
item.description: We will be having regular check-up quizzes. Quizzes will be very short—normally 10 minutes. Their purpose is to check in on your understanding and to incentivize your ongoing efforts, should they require a hint of additional incentive. Some quizzes will be open notes and homework, meaning that you can copy answers from your own homework (though not from anyone else). In those cases, the quizzes will exactly repeat some homework problems.

item.title: Test 2
item.description: Test 2 may include the following: Offer the definition of “logically valid.” Answer true-false questions using the terms/concepts from the vocabulary list, very similar to the true-false exercises you’ve done previously. Given a logically valid argument expressed in English, construct a symbolization key for the atomic sentences and/or names and predicates within them, in a way that’s adequate to bring out the logical validity of the argument. Using a symbolization key, symbolize English sentences in TFL (truth-functional/sentential logic) and FOL (first-order/predicate logic).
